	Block Elements Vs Inline Elements
	
	Block Elements
	
		-> Entire width of your browsers
		
		-> It always starts in new line
		
		-> Block elements height and width can be controlled using CSS or stylings
		
		
	Inline Elements
	
		-> only takes content width
		-> Height and width cannot be controlled by Stylings
		-> Starting will be based on previous elements
		
		-> Inline  + Inline
		
		-> inline + Block
		
				inline
				block
				
		-> Block + inline
			
				block
				inline
				
		-> Inline -> block
		
		<label>
			<h1></h1>
		</label>
		
	Inline-Block
	
		display: inline-block		
		
		-> content width
		-> Height and width can be controlled using stylings
		

	-> <span>

	Positioning an element:
	
		position : ${value}
		
		fixed:
		
			position: fixed;
			
				-> Fetch out ur element from document screen
				-> it will attach your element to window || tab || view-port
	
			decide the position
			
				top, right, bottom , left;
				
				top: 0px;
				right: 0px;
				
		relative:
		
			position: relative;
			
				-> Fetch out your element from document screen
				
				-> within the same place
				
				-> relative elements are normal elements but can be controlled through position properties
				
				-> relative elements move relative to the elements starting point (at the time of rendering)
				
				
		absolute:
		
			position: absolute;
			
				-> Not to view port
				
				-> it will move relative to nearest relative parent element
				
				-> absolute positioning always need to be used within an relative parent.
				
				-> if not by default it will be attached to body tag as body tag is relative by default
				
		default:
		
			position: static;
			
		position: sticky;

		}
		
		
		@SomeAnnotations
		export class MyComponent {
		
		}

			'template' : `

			`,
			'styles' : [ `.my-class {

	Data Binding:
	
		Data from our controller to HTML
		
		
		We have two types of Data Binding:
		
			1. One way data binding
				-> Contoller to HTML , TS file to HTML
					
					myStr: string = 'string1';
					
					getData() { return 'str'; }
					
					getData() { return { a: 1 } }
					
					<p> </p>
					
					=> String interpolation
					
						{{ }} => We could able to present our component variables
						
						<p> {{ myStr }} </p>
						
						{{ 1 + 1 }} => 2
						
						{{ getData() }} = > ('str').toString() => 'str'
						
						
						{{ getData() }} = > ({{a : 1 } ).toString() => [object Object]
						
						{{ variable ||  any expression that can be evaluvated and result as string ().toString() }}
					
					=> Property Binding
						
						[]
						
						<p id, name class style, innerHTML, innerText>
	
						</p>
						
						<p [innerHTML]="myStr" ></p>
					
					=> we should not mix both
						<p [innerHTML]="{{myStr}}"> </p>
						
				
				-> HTML to controller, HTML to ts
				
					Form controls
					
						input, buttons, checkbox
						
						
					Event Binding
					
						() -> 
					
					button
						onclick, onchange
						(click)
					
					input
						onchange, onfocus
						
					<button (click)="getData('ar', 'ad', $event)" > Click to update value </button>

	Directives

	1. Pre-defined Directives
		Two types of directives:
		
		 i) Attribute Directives
		 
			Will add or enhance ur element
				styles, classes, element always presents in HTML Tree
			
			it does not have control to remove ur element
			
			[]
			
			ngStyle
			
				[ngStyle]="{ background-color: 'red', 'color' : 'blue' }"
				
			ngClass
			
				[ngClass]="{ 'class names ' : boolean (true | false) }"
				
			on one element we can use multiple AD 
			
			<p [ngStyle]="" [ngClass]=""> </p> 
		 
		 
		 ii) Structural Directive
		 
				It will on add or removing elements from HTML dom tree
				
				*
				
				ngIf
					used to hide and show ur element
					*ngIf="truthy | falsy'
					else
				ngFor
					Looping or iterating ur object
					
					*ngFor="let item of items" *ngFor="let i of [1,2,3,4,5]"
					
					<p *ngFor="let item of items">

						{{ item.name }}
					</p>
					
					
					<p *ngFor="let item of items; index as ind; first as isFirstItem; 
												  last as isLastItem; odd as isOddIndexItem;
												  even as isEvenItem">

						{{ item }}
					</p
					
					<p> {{ item }} </p>
				
				ngSwitch
				
					*ngSwitch=="str"					
					
					<p ngSwitchCase="'MyFirstComponent'"> </p>		

					
				<ng-container *ngIf="showTag" >
					<p *ngFor="let item of items"> </p>
				</ng-container>

		How to work with Router Gaurd
		
			1. A service class 
			
			2. It implements an interface called CanActivate (Angular Router)
			
			3. We need override canActivate method of interface
			
			4. within canActivate we have to whatever calculation or computation we need to do
			
			5. Finally we need to return a boolean.
			
			6. True -> allows the navigation
			
			7. False -> navigation will be prevented.
		
			8. Register the gaurd to whatever the path u want to protect.
			
				canActivate key in Routes
				
				canActivateChild key in Routes
